news_summary: Today's news highlights impressive personal achievements in securing competitive grants alongside fascinating insights into ancient wildlife and Neanderthal diets.
news_summary_fr: Les nouvelles d'aujourd'hui mettent en lumière des réalisations personnelles impressionnantes qui ont permis d'obtenir des bourses compétitives, ainsi que des informations fascinantes sur la faune ancienne et le régime alimentaire des Néandertaliens.
news_summary_es: Las noticias de hoy destacan impresionantes logros personales en la obtención de becas competitivas, junto con fascinantes conocimientos sobre la fauna antigua y la dieta de los neandertales.

articles.title: I won three competitive grants in a row. Here’s how I learnt what to do
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 24 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-01627-6It took time and rejections to understand what granting agencies look for. This is how I picked up application-writing skills.
articles.content:
Jingming Cai says he deliberately shaped his PhD's focus to prepare for future applicationsCredit: Cavan Images/Getty

After completing my PhD in engineering in September 2018, I set out to navigate the world of early-career fellowships — a path that taught me as much about resilience and strategy as it did about research.

After experiencing two rejections, rewriting my proposals and learning from every round of feedback, I have secured three major awards over the past five years: a Humboldt Research Fellowship in Germany, a Marie Skłodowska-Curie Postdoctoral Fellowship (MSCA-PF) from the European Union and a Discovery Early Career Researcher Award (DECRA) from the Australian Research Council. These totalled around US$600,000 in funding, which supported my early-stage research across multiple countries. Now, I’m an associate professor at the School of Civil Engineering at Southeast University in Nanjing, China, where I conduct research on energy technologies for buildings.

All three fellowships are highly competitive — for instance, the success rates for the MSCA-PF and DECRA were both around 15% when I applied. Each application process pushed me to reflect not only on how to write a convincing proposal, but also on who I am as a researcher, what kind of work I want to do and how to communicate that to others. Here are some lessons that I learnt the hard way — and that might help others going through the same process.

Start preparing before you finish your PhD

The best applications don’t start with a call for proposals — they start months, and sometimes years, earlier. In the final year of my PhD, I became aware of several major international fellowships for early-career researchers. With these opportunities in mind, I deliberately shaped my work to strengthen my CV and prepare for future applications. I focused on building a clear research identity: publishing in the niche but promising field of thermoelectric materials for buildings, and collaborating internationally. This helped to demonstrate that I could work across borders. These shifts weren’t always straightforward — I had to take care that my activities remained aligned with my doctoral objectives without compromising the integrity of my research.

For example, I actively took part in international academic conferences on emerging energy technologies, even though they were not entirely relevant to my core research area. These experiences later helped me to identify institutions that would be suitable hosts if I attracted funding, and to collect strong letters of recommendation.

I also learnt the importance of being flexible with my research direction. Early on I focused entirely on structural design in buildings, but I later realized that combining structural design with energy research was better suited to my strengths. It also aligned more closely with emerging needs in the field, and so would be relevant to more calls for grant funding. I think similar opportunities exist in the natural sciences, particularly because many areas are now integrating with digital tools such as artificial intelligence and the use of big data, so expertise in those areas is transferable.

Choosing a research direction that plays to your strengths and can respond to developments and demands in the field can make a real difference. I attended a number of interdisciplinary talks, which gave me a broad view of where the field was heading. I decided to shape my direction accordingly, while keeping my own interests in mind. I tried to be as independent as I could in choosing a research direction: after all, the grants I was applying for were specifically to build my own research direction.

Use early applications to practise and build confidence

I submitted my first MSCA-PF application shortly after finishing my PhD — and was rejected. The core proposal was around 15 pages long and required detailed planning of research content, collaborations and implementation. I had only three months to prepare it, and I underestimated the importance of a well-structured narrative. As a result, the submission lacked coherence and clarity, and didn’t address the scientific questions in enough depth. For example, my methodology did not include enough detail.

I asked for feedback and started again. I rewrote the proposal from scratch: clarified my role in the project, restructured the scientific goals so that they were more focused, with concrete and feasible methods, and worked closely with my collaborators and host institution. The second time around, the proposal scored 98.8 out of 100 and was awarded €189,000 (US$220,000). I used this to start my work on building energy technologies, where I made advances in the field of thermoelectric devices. My colleagues and I developed the most energy-efficient building thermoelectric module known so far, with the potential to convert urban waste heat into electricity and help to mitigate the growing challenges of the urban heat-island effect and energy crisis.

Jingming Cai learned from repeated rejection to win some big time fellowships.Credit: Jingming Cai

For those starting out, I recommend applying to fellowships with simpler formats and flexible timelines — such as those offered by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science or the Humboldt Foundation in Germany. These programmes have a more streamlined application process, focusing on the applicant’s potential and research idea, rather than requiring very detailed project planning and implementation, as the MSCA-PF does. The fellowships are highly respected and are excellent practice for applying to more complex programmes, such as European Research Council funding competitions.

Tell a story — don’t just give a technical plan

The biggest mistake I made early on was treating a fellowship application like a journal submission. My first MSCA-PF draft was packed with bullet points, dense data tables and technical language. But I learnt that reviewers aren’t just evaluating scientific merit — they’re also looking for alignment with their goals, potential to become an independent researcher and a clear narrative. And, of course, how the proposed work would contribute to solving any specific scientific or societal challenges that the fellowship aims to support.

What made the difference in my revised application was learning how to tell a compelling story: who I was, what I had done, what gap I saw in the field and how this project, in this environment, would help me to grow. I included a tailored training plan, showed how the fellowship would support my long-term goals and outlined the societal relevance of the work.

I followed a simple structure:

Background. Introduce the project using a narrative that leads from ‘everybody knows’ to ‘nobody knows’ — start with widely understood context, then narrow down to the specific research gap.

Challenge. Describe the technical bottleneck and explain why this project is needed to overcome it.

Innovation. Explain what makes the idea original and how it differs from existing approaches.

Implementation. Lay out a detailed and feasible plan to ensure timely and effective delivery of the project.

Impact. Clarify the scientific and socio-economic benefits of the project.

This breakdown made it easier for reviewers to follow the logic and understand the value of each component. I avoided jargon and assumed the reviewers were smart scientists, but not necessarily experts in my subfield.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights an individual's achievement in winning three competitive grants consecutively, emphasizing perseverance and learning from rejection. This serves as an inspiring story about overcoming challenges and acquiring valuable skills, which can motivate others in academic and professional pursuits.
articles.personality_title: How I won three big grants by learning from rejection
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Jingming Cai completed his PhD in engineering in 2018 and aimed to secure early-career research fellowships. This path involved tough competition and several setbacks.

**What happened**
After two initial rejections, Jingming carefully rewrote his grant proposals, paying close attention to feedback from reviewers. He focused his research to match what granting agencies look for, which helped him win three major awards in five years.

**Impact**
This journey taught Jingming valuable skills in writing strong applications and handling setbacks with resilience. His success is a great reminder that persistence and learning from feedback can lead to big achievements.

**What's next step**
Jingming plans to keep refining his proposals and continue applying for fellowships, using the skills he developed to support his research career.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Learning from rejection and focusing your work on what funders want can help you succeed in winning competitive grants.
articles.personality_title_fr: Comment j'ai gagné trois grosses bourses en apprenant de mes refus
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Jingming Cai a terminé son doctorat en ingénierie en 2018 et a voulu obtenir des bourses pour jeunes chercheurs. Ce parcours a été très compétitif et parfois difficile.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
Après deux refus, Jingming a réécrit ses demandes en tenant compte des retours des évaluateurs. Il a orienté ses recherches pour répondre aux attentes des organismes financeurs, ce qui lui a permis de décrocher trois grandes bourses en cinq ans.

**Impact**
Cette expérience lui a donné des compétences précieuses en rédaction de dossiers et en persévérance. Son succès montre qu’apprendre de ses erreurs peut mener à de grandes réussites.

**La prochaine étape**
Jingming compte continuer à améliorer ses demandes et postuler à d’autres bourses, en utilisant les compétences acquises pour avancer dans sa carrière.

**Conclusion en une phrase**
Apprendre de ses refus et adapter son travail aux attentes des financeurs aide à réussir à obtenir des bourses compétitives.
articles.personality_title_es: Cómo gané tres grandes becas aprendiendo de los rechazos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Jingming Cai terminó su doctorado en ingeniería en 2018 y buscó obtener becas para investigadores jóvenes. Este camino fue muy competitivo y desafiante.

**Qué pasó**
Después de dos rechazos, Jingming reescribió sus solicitudes prestando mucha atención a los comentarios de los evaluadores. Enfocó su investigación para alinearse con lo que buscan las agencias financiadoras, lo que le ayudó a ganar tres grandes premios en cinco años.

**Impacto**
Esta experiencia le enseñó habilidades valiosas para redactar buenas solicitudes y enfrentar los contratiempos con perseverancia. Su éxito recuerda que aprender de la retroalimentación puede llevar a grandes logros.

**Próximo paso**
Jingming planea seguir mejorando sus propuestas y aplicando a más becas, usando lo aprendido para avanzar en su carrera investigadora.

**Conclusión en una frase**
Aprender de los rechazos y enfocar tu trabajo en lo que buscan los financiadores puede ayudarte a ganar becas competitivas.
articles.image_prompt: An inspiring detailed painting of an open, glowing book resting on a desk surrounded by blueprints and scientific tools, with three ascending glowing orbs above it symbolizing successive research grants, set against a soft background of interconnected architectural structures and abstract energy waves in calm natural tones, evoking growth, resilience, and innovation in early-career scientific research.

articles.title: Rumble in the Miocene: terror bird versus caiman
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 23 July 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02308-0Toothmarks on a fossilized bone tell a story of two mega-predators.
articles.content: Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles and JavaScript.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses a scientific discovery involving fossilized evidence of interactions between prehistoric mega-predators, which contributes to our understanding of natural history and evolution. While it is not directly about human welfare or environmental progress, it represents a positive advancement in scientific knowledge.
articles.personality_title: Fossil clues reveal epic showdown between ancient terror bird and giant caiman
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists recently uncovered fossilized bones showing evidence of a battle between two giant prehistoric predators: a terror bird and a large caiman. These creatures lived millions of years ago during the Miocene era, a time when Earth was full of massive and powerful animals.

**What happened**
Researchers found tooth marks on a fossilized bone that tell the story of a fierce encounter. The marks match those made by a giant caiman’s teeth, suggesting it attacked a terror bird. Terror birds were large flightless birds that ruled as top hunters back then. This discovery sheds light on how these ancient animals interacted and competed for survival.

**Impact**
This finding is exciting because it adds a vivid piece to the puzzle of Earth’s natural history. It helps scientists understand predator behaviors and how ecosystems worked millions of years ago. Knowing more about these interactions can also inform how species evolve and adapt over time.

**What's next step**
Scientists plan to continue examining fossil sites and look for more evidence of ancient animal encounters. They hope to learn even more about the dynamics between different species and how prehistoric ecosystems thrived or changed.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Fossil tooth marks reveal a thrilling clash between a terror bird and a giant caiman, deepening our understanding of prehistoric life and predator battles.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des indices fossiles révèlent un combat épique entre un oiseau-terreur ancien et un caïman géant
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Des scientifiques ont récemment découvert des os fossilisés montrant des preuves d’un combat entre deux grands prédateurs préhistoriques : un oiseau-terreur et un grand caïman. Ces créatures vivaient il y a des millions d’années, durant l’ère du Miocène, une période où la Terre regorgeait d’animaux puissants et massifs.

**Ce qui s’est passé**
Les chercheurs ont trouvé des marques de dents sur un os fossile racontant une rencontre féroce. Ces marques correspondent à celles laissées par les dents d’un grand caïman, suggérant qu’il a attaqué un oiseau-terreur. Ces oiseaux, incapables de voler, étaient alors des chasseurs dominants. Cette découverte éclaire la façon dont ces animaux anciens interagissaient et rivalisaient pour survivre.

**Impact**
Cette découverte est passionnante car elle ajoute une pièce vivante au puzzle de l’histoire naturelle de la Terre. Elle aide les scientifiques à mieux comprendre les comportements des prédateurs et le fonctionnement des écosystèmes il y a des millions d’années. Mieux connaître ces interactions aide aussi à comprendre comment les espèces évoluent et s’adaptent.

**Prochaine étape**
Les scientifiques prévoient de continuer à étudier les sites fossiles et chercher d’autres preuves de rencontres entre animaux anciens. Ils espèrent en apprendre davantage sur la dynamique entre espèces et comment les écosystèmes préhistoriques évoluaient.

**Message clé en une phrase**
Les marques de dents fossilisées révèlent un affrontement passionnant entre un oiseau-terreur et un grand caïman, enrichissant notre compréhension de la vie préhistorique et des combats entre prédateurs.
articles.personality_title_es: Pistas fósiles revelan un enfrentamiento épico entre un ave terror y un caimán gigante
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Científicos han descubierto recientemente huesos fosilizados que muestran evidencia de una batalla entre dos grandes depredadores prehistóricos: un ave terror y un caimán gigante. Estas criaturas vivieron hace millones de años durante la era del Mioceno, un tiempo en que la Tierra estaba llena de animales grandes y poderosos.

**Qué pasó**
Los investigadores encontraron marcas de dientes en un hueso fosilizado que cuentan la historia de un encuentro feroz. Las marcas coinciden con las hechas por los dientes de un caimán gigante, sugiriendo que atacó a un ave terror. Estas aves, que no podían volar, eran cazadores dominantes en esa época. Este hallazgo aporta luz sobre cómo estos animales antiguos interactuaban y competían para sobrevivir.

**Impacto**
Este descubrimiento es emocionante porque añade una pieza vital al rompecabezas de la historia natural de la Tierra. Ayuda a los científicos a entender mejor el comportamiento de los depredadores y cómo funcionaban los ecosistemas hace millones de años. Conocer más sobre estas interacciones también ayuda a entender cómo las especies evolucionan y se adaptan.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos planean seguir explorando sitios fósiles y buscar más evidencias de encuentros entre animales antiguos. Esperan aprender aún más sobre la dinámica entre diferentes especies y cómo prosperaban o cambiaban los ecosistemas prehistóricos.

**Mensaje en una frase**
Las marcas de dientes fósiles revelan un emocionante choque entre un ave terror y un caimán gigante, profundizando nuestra comprensión de la vida prehistórica y las batallas de depredadores.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm-toned painting of a majestic terror bird with vivid plumage facing off against a sturdy caiman in a lush Miocene wetland, both animals depicted with gentle expressions and natural earthy colors, surrounded by softly rendered prehistoric vegetation under a calm sky.

articles.title: Neanderthals were probably maggot-munchers, not hyper-carnivores
articles.summary: It has been claimed Neanderthals ate a huge amount of meat based on isotope ratios in their bones – but the explanation could instead be a diet rich in maggots
articles.content:
It has been claimed Neanderthals ate a huge amount of meat based on isotope ratios in their bones – but the explanation could instead be a diet rich in maggots

Maggots in rotting meat could have been an important part of ancient diets Chronicle/Alamy

Neanderthals may not have been the hyper-carnivores we thought they were. It has been claimed, based on the nitrogen isotope ratios in their bones, that our ancient relatives ate little besides meat. But these ratios can also be explained by a more balanced omnivorous diet that included a lot of maggots, as well as plant-based food.

“Masses of maggots are these easily scoopable, collectible, nutrient-rich resource,” says Melanie Beasley at Purdue University, Indiana.

Advertisement

There is lots of evidence that they were routinely eaten in many societies in the past, and they are still consumed in some places today, she says. Some reindeer hunters regard certain maggots as a treat that they actively cultivate, for instance, while casu martzu, a cheese that contains live maggots, is a delicacy in Sardinia.

Nitrogen has two stable isotopes, nitrogen-14 and nitrogen-15. The lighter isotope is more likely to be lost from living organisms than the heavy one, so, as matter moves up food chains, the ratio of nitrogen-15 to nitrogen-14 increases.

Looking at the isotope ratios in collagen inside fossil bones can therefore tell us about the diet of those animals, with carnivores having higher ratios than herbivores. But when researchers started looking at the ratios in the bones of Neanderthals, they found something surprising: even higher ratios than those seen in lions and hyenas. “So there became this narrative that Neanderthals were these hyper-carnivores very focused on big game hunting,” says Beasley.

Subscriber-only newsletter Sign up to Our Human Story Each month, Michael Marshall unearths the latest news and ideas about ancient humans, evolution, archaeology and more. Sign up to newsletter

But many researchers don’t buy this idea. For one thing, the bones of Homo sapiens living in prehistoric times have similar ratios – and these humans couldn’t have survived on lean meat alone. “It’s actually physically not possible,” says Beasley. “You’ll die of what early explorers called ‘rabbit starvation’.”

The issue is that if a person’s diet is too rich in protein, their body can’t mop up all the toxic breakdown products, such as ammonia.

There is also now plenty of direct evidence that Neanderthals did eat plants, too, for instance from studies of their dental calculus. So why were their nitrogen-15 ratios so high?

Back in 2017, John Speth at the University of Michigan suggested it could be because Neanderthals stored meat and ate it later in a rotten state. As meat rots, gases like ammonia are given off, which should result in nitrogen-15 enrichment.

At the time, Beasley was applying to do research at the “body farm” at the University of Tennessee where human cadavers are studied as they decay to help with crime scene analysis. She realised she could test Speth’s idea alongside the forensic research – and while she was at it, she also looked at the maggots in the bodies.

Together with Speth and Julie Lesnik at Wayne State University, Michigan, Beasley found that nitrogen isotope ratios do increase as muscle tissue rots, but only by a modest amount. There is, however, a much bigger jump seen in the maggots of various kinds feeding on the corpses.

These are just initial results, but they show that eating a diet very high in meat isn’t the only possible explanation for the isotope ratios in Neanderthals and ancient Homo sapiens, says Beasley. She thinks those ratios are probably due to a combination of factors – the storage, processing and cooking of meat, as well as the consumption of maggots.

“This is an exciting new study, and I think it goes a long way toward making sense of the strange results that have come out of isotope studies in Neanderthals and other Stone Age hominins over the last couple of decades,” says Herman Pontzer at Duke University in North Carolina.

“I find the evidence here pretty convincing, that consumption of maggots and similar larvae explains the ‘hyper-carnivore’ signal we’ve been seeing in previous fossil isotope work,” he says.

The work also adds to the evidence that a so-called palaeo diet should include rotten meat and maggots, says Beasley. “All the people who want to go true ‘palaeo’, they need to start thinking about fermenting their meat and letting the flies access them.”

Journal reference: Science Advances DOI: 10.1126/sciadv.adt7466
articles.reasoning: The article presents a new scientific insight into Neanderthal diets, challenging previous assumptions and expanding our understanding of human evolution. While it is not directly related to health or environment, it is a positive scientific development that can inspire curiosity and knowledge.
articles.personality_title: Neanderthals likely enjoyed maggots, not just meat
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context**
Scientists long believed Neanderthals ate mostly meat, based on certain chemicals found in their bones. These chemicals, called nitrogen isotopes, were thought to show a heavy meat diet.

**What happened**
New research suggests these nitrogen isotope levels can also come from eating maggots that lived on rotting meat. Maggots are baby flies that feed on decaying animal flesh, possibly making up a big part of Neanderthals’ diet.

**Impact**
This discovery changes how we see Neanderthals—not just as meat-hungry hunters, but as clever eaters who might have gotten nutrition from unexpected sources. It gives us a richer picture of human evolution and ancient diets.

**What's next step**
Scientists will study more ancient remains and look closely at other chemical clues to better understand what Neanderthals really ate. This could lead to new insights about how early humans survived and adapted.

**One-sentence takeaway**
Neanderthals likely had a more varied diet than thought, including maggots, showing their resourcefulness in finding food.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les Néandertaliens mangeaient probablement des asticots, pas seulement de la viande
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte**
Les scientifiques pensaient depuis longtemps que les Néandertaliens mangeaient principalement de la viande, en se basant sur certains composants chimiques trouvés dans leurs os, appelés isotopes d'azote.

**Ce qui s'est passé**
De nouvelles recherches montrent que ces niveaux d'isotopes peuvent aussi venir de la consommation d'asticots vivant sur de la viande en décomposition. Les asticots sont les larves de mouches qui se nourrissent de viande pourrie, et ils auraient pu être une part importante de l'alimentation des Néandertaliens.

**Impact**
Cette découverte change notre vision des Néandertaliens : non seulement de gros mangeurs de viande, mais aussi des mangeurs ingénieux qui tiraient leur nutrition de sources inattendues. Cela enrichit notre compréhension de l'évolution humaine et des régimes alimentaires anciens.

**Prochaine étape**
Les chercheurs vont étudier plus d'ossements anciens et analyser d'autres indices chimiques pour mieux comprendre ce que les Néandertaliens mangeaient vraiment. Cela pourrait apporter de nouvelles connaissances sur leur survie et leur adaptation.

**Une phrase à retenir**
Les Néandertaliens avaient probablement une alimentation plus variée qu'on ne le pensait, incluant des asticots, montrant leur ingéniosité pour trouver de la nourriture.
articles.personality_title_es: Los neandertales probablemente comían gusanos, no solo carne
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto**
Los científicos creían que los neandertales comían principalmente carne, basándose en ciertos químicos encontrados en sus huesos, llamados isótopos de nitrógeno.

**Qué pasó**
Una nueva investigación sugiere que estos niveles de isótopos también pueden provenir de comer gusanos que vivían en carne podrida. Los gusanos son larvas de moscas que se alimentan de carne en descomposición y podrían haber sido una parte importante de la dieta neandertal.

**Impacto**
Este hallazgo cambia cómo vemos a los neandertales: no solo como grandes cazadores de carne, sino como comedores ingeniosos que obtenían nutrición de fuentes inesperadas. Esto nos da una imagen más completa de la evolución humana y las dietas antiguas.

**Próximo paso**
Los científicos estudiarán más restos antiguos y examinarán otras pistas químicas para entender mejor qué comían realmente los neandertales. Esto podría traer nuevas ideas sobre cómo los primeros humanos sobrevivieron y se adaptaron.

**Un resumen en una frase**
Los neandertales probablemente tenían una dieta más variada de lo que se pensaba, incluyendo gusanos, demostrando su capacidad para encontrar alimento.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of a prehistoric camp scene showing symbolic elements: a stylized stone spear resting beside a rustic wooden platter holding a cluster of glowing maggots nestled in aged, textured meat, with soft earth tones and gentle light highlighting the coexistence of ancient human survival, nature’s cycle, and the unexpected role of maggots in the Neanderthal diet.
